Situation A. Strategies from Everett Middle School Students

The following strategies were used to answer the question in the Initial Challenge. For each strategy, explain how it will or will not help answers the questions.
Zane's Strategy Our group used a table to determine how much money we would have to charge just to cover our rental cost of $750 which is the break-even point.

Molada's Strategy Our group also made a table, but then we looked at the pattern in the table and tried to write an equation that relates the cost per person c to the number of people n who buy tickets. But we could not find an equation, so we made a graph of the data and used it to make predictions.

Xander's Strategy We could see there was not a constant rate of change in the Zane’s table. So, we made a graph like Molada’s. It looked a bit like our bridge length data, so we tried to find an inverse variation equation to fit.

Situation B. Fixed Cost

The students decide to charge $5 per person for the event. They want to know
  • The amount of money A they collect if n people buy tickets.
  • The amount of the profit P they will have after they pay for the rental cost.
1. Write an equation that will help them predict the amount of money they collect if they charge $5 per person.
2. Write an equation that will help them predict the profit if they charge $5 per person.
3. Sketch a graph of each equation.
4. Do the graphs indicate a linear relationship or an inverse variation? Explain.
5. How would you use the graphs to show how many tickets must be sold in order to make a profit? How would you use the equations to decide how many tickets must be sold to make a profit?
